posts.cooked: We have a Rev Blinkin that works say 90% of the time. The 10% is that it resets the strip mode to the 5v strip randomly. We’re using the 12v mode to show cube/cone mode for our intake. There’s no chance anything is hitting the button while running and you seemingly can’t set the strip mode over pwm. Has anyone else encountered a similar issue? The 12V is plugged into the pdp but the lights have never turned off in correlation with any specific event like a brownout or a hard hit etc.  Could it be ESD ? Anything we can do to mitigate that?

link_counts.title: Rev Blinkin LED controller switching from 5V to 12V output randomly

posts.name: Zach
posts.cooked: We’ve been having the same issue, but with our blinkins occasionally switching from 5v to 12v. They don’t switch at the same time, so I wouldn’t expect it to be related to robot conditions like a brown out

posts.name: Nate
posts.cooked: We also experience this occasionally. Never in a match though so its an fix prematch.

posts.name: Abi
posts.cooked: We’ve been having the exact same issue. We are using a 5v strip, and the Blinkin strip mode will occasionally switch to 12V randomly, sometimes mid-match. We’re also using a PWM connection to the Rio to controll the light colors from our operator controller. We have been fixing it be re-entering the setup mode and re-selecting the 5v strip. Just a weird bug I guess?

posts.name: Bryn Dole - programming mentor FRC 2930
posts.cooked:
Our team has had the same problem. The Blinkin switching from 12v to 5v mode, sometimes mid-match, and then returning to 12V mode after power cycling the robot.

In our case the blinkin had come lose from its moorings and  we suspect a nearby cable had managed to depress the 5V/12V mode button. Without also simultaneously pressing both buttons for ~6 seconds the settings would not be saved and would revert to the previous 12V mode after a power cycle.

Screenshot 2023-03-31 at 7.44.51 AM 1818×534 290 KB

Screenshot 2023-03-31 at 7.44.51 AM 1818×534 290 KB

Screenshot 2023-03-31 at 7.44.51 AM 1818×534 290 KB

Our solution was to better attach the blinkin to the robot and to gaff tape a bolt over the voltage select button so that it could only be depressed with something small and pointy.

We’ve only had one day of running the robot after this fix, so we can’t say if this is the definitive fix.

REV Blinkin manual for reference https://www.revrobotics.com/content/docs/REV-11-1105-UM.pdf

posts.name: Bryn Dole - programming mentor FRC 2930
posts.cooked:
Despite better securing our blinkin and protecting the 5v/12v mode button with a nut and some gaff tape, we still had our blinkin change modes on us during practice this weekend. The plastic casing on this one has come loose, damaged from prying it up after being VHB taped. We suspect that the button is getting “pressed” when the robot drives over hard bumps.

Next steps are to either

physically desolder the button. I’m pretty sure the blinkin counts as a “custom circuit” and this is not in violation of “modifying robot parts” rules. OR

flash the blinking with a custom firmware and disable 5V mode.  Firmware and instructions from Rev are here: GitHub - REVrobotics/Blinkin-Firmware: Firmware for REV Blinkin REV-11-1105

Hey Rev Robotics @Greg_Needel maybe the next version of the blinkin can have a switch or jumper to set the voltage?

link_counts.title: GitHub - REVrobotics/Blinkin-Firmware: Firmware for REV Blinkin REV-11-1105

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked: We also had this happen once – it’s highly unlikely anything pressed the button, but we have taken/given some hard hits this year, so I’m not quite willing to say impossible…

posts.name: Dustin Benedict
posts.cooked:
We’ve been experiencing the same / similar problems with our Blinkin, based on a bunch of testing, it seems to boil down to (1) of (2) Failure Modes:

Failure Mode #1: Blinkin Switches from 5V mode to 12V mode while operating.

As a sanity check, did a standard vibration / move / wiggle / pull all of the wiring to check for loose wires, could not force a failure through external manual inputs. From here, checked commands being sent, if there were some sequence of commands that could be send (i.e. sent different PWM signals) to the blinkin to see if we could force it to change mode - nothing conclusive, after trying a bunch of different things - the only thing that we found that seemed to have any repeatable effect was the overall Battery / System Voltage. Crashes were most likely to occur on a battery with a resting voltage of below 12.4-12.3V and when Voltage intermittently dropped to below 11.5V. In an hour or so of testing, this was the only thing that seemed to make a difference - when the system voltage dropped it was almost like the Blinkin reset itself into 12V mode.

Failure Mode #2: Blinkin Remains in 5V Mode, Registers Valid Input Signal, However Lights are not on / not responding.

Second Failure mode was a bit weirder to quantify, since all of the Blinkin Status LEDs appear correct, there was just no output. We tried various PWM Outputs, Turning Outputs Off Completely, Disabling the Robot, Etc - and it was almost as if the Blinkin had just “Crashed” and the Output Became Unresponsive. A Power Cycle always corrects the problem, and the Blinkin Starts back up in 5V Mode.

In Further Testing, lowering Strip Brightness Seemed to Improve stability, at least when the battery was fresh and when runtime was relatively short. (As in not much longer than a standard match). The Problems seem to become more prevalent with up time - whether this is actually a factor, or just further confirmation that as the System Voltage Decreases, weird thing happen, I’m not sure.

For further details on our specific setup - we are using (2) of the Standard REV. 5V Addressable LED Strips for a Total Strip Length of 2 Meters, with the only modification of note being that the wiring has been extended by about 1 meter(ish) to route them across the robot.

Would be nice to see something concrete on this - since digging through threads and a few other references, it looks like this has been an issue for a few years, and most teams just give up and go to Rio Based control, which is an option, just not for us in our current timeframe (we compete again this week). I’m hoping that this may be fixed by something as simple as a 12V Regulator on the incoming power to ensure that the Blinkin Generally always sees a normalized 12V Source, but if it were that easy, I’d expect someone to have noted this by now…

Also, our current code generally shifts between some number of the Blinkin Standard Patterns using Color 1 (For us, Gold) and Color 2 (Purple) for Cone / Cube States and a couple of Green Confirmation Pulses / Solid Green for ~2s. Should all be within the realm of sanity unless there’s some hard limit on the Blinkin’s ability to respond to signal changes.
We also get this issue once in a while. Unfortunately the kids state that our spare is also not working correctly. Wish these were still in stock.

posts.name: Kaleb Dodd
posts.cooked: We’ve had this issue when we used a blinkin in 2019 and 2022, it doesn’t happen all the time but often enough in real matches that it can cause issues if your drive team is used to the leds for feedback.  We have since switched to controlling leds with the roboRIO instead.

posts.name: Bryn Dole - programming mentor FRC 2930
posts.cooked:
Our team created our own custom blinkin firmware image, using the code from Rev GitHub - REVrobotics/Blinkin-Firmware: Firmware for REV Blinkin REV-11-1105 We changed the code to disable the command to switch from 12V to 5V and set the default mode to 12V.

We still had the blinkin flip from 12V to 5V mode, but only once over 3 days at DCMP. I think there’s a software bug in the firmware code that is overwriting the configured voltage.

link_counts.title: GitHub - REVrobotics/Blinkin-Firmware: Firmware for REV Blinkin REV-11-1105

posts.name: dyanoshak
posts.cooked:
We believe what is happening is caused by a spurious pulse when some robots start up or shut down. This pulse happens to match a command code we use when testing the Blinkin at the factory, and this code switches the strip mode.

We are working on updating our documentation to include these command codes, but here is a sequence that you can perform in robot code that should get the strip back to what you want:

1. Send the pulse (listed below) for the necessary strip type. The Status LED should turn to solid magenta and the Strip Select LED will remain the same as it was before the command was sent.

5V Strip = 2125 μs 12V Strip = 2145 μs

2. Send the pulse for a pattern different than the pattern that the Blinkin was originally displaying. At this time the LEDs should change to the new strip and be set with the pattern you chose. The Status LED will go back to solid blue and the Strip Select LED will switch to the strip type you selected in Step 1.

3. Send the pulse for the original desired pattern to your Blinkin

​Our apologies for the confusion, but hopefully this will get you all back up and running.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
Based on this comment (FPGA cycle is 5.005ms):

Also (see PWM Motor Controllers in Depth — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation ): “can vary the pulse width in 2000 steps of ~.001ms each around the midpoint (1000 steps in each direction around the midpoint)”.  The PWM center value is nominally 1.5ms.

So, 2125μs = 2.125ms = 1.5ms + 0.625ms ~> 1000 + 625 = 1625; 2145μs = 2.145ms = 1.5ms + 0.645ms ~> 1000 + 645 = 1645.

The API to use with these numbers would be PWM.SetRaw().

We only had this happen once, and we just used the button to manually switch back.  But it might make for a little offseason project, checking these timings on a scope and then adding the logic to run through the listed steps as part of initialization.  The tricky part is that PWM outputs are disabled until the robot itself is enabled, but that’s easy enough to manage.

link_counts.title: PWM Motor Controllers in Depth — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Michael Hills
posts.cooked: Our experience at FRC 2930 (I’m working with randomstring) is that this happens, not at startup, but at some random time during operation, sometimes in the middle of a match.  I am theorizing that this is caused by a pulse that is measured as between 2100-2130us, triggering the command to either turn off or switch to 5v mode.  I haven’t done any testing of this theory yet to see if there could be a spurious pulse generated by the RoboRio as it is switching PWM pulse widths, or if there could be a measurement error in the Blinkin.  I have identified the potential for up to 6.625us measurement error in the Blinkin firmware if the rising or falling PWM edge is detected while the timer ISR is active (see Timing the Timekeeper – Arduino Craft Corner ), but that alone should not be enough to cause the Blinkin to turn off or switch 5v/12v.  I think to use the workaround provided by Rev above would require sending the command to set the correct mode very frequently to ensure that when the LEDs turned off, they would come back on very soon afterwards.

link_counts.title: Timing the Timekeeper – Arduino Craft Corner

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: EE mentor with the Sonic Squirrels

posts.name: Michael Hills
posts.cooked: One thing some people have observed is that at least a couple of times, the LEDs have gone out after a significant impact, even though the robot then continues operating normally (but without LEDs).  I’m not sure if that is true of every case.  Is it possible that an impact would cause the RoboRio to disable the robot (shutting off PWM) for a very short (unnoticeable) period of time, but since the PWM gets stopped and restarted, it could trigger the spurious pulse mentioned by dynashak?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: EE mentor with the Sonic Squirrels

posts.name: Jill
posts.cooked: I can’t speak to any of your hypotheses, but I can add further anecdotal evidence of the LEDs coming off the blinkin shutting down after hard impacts. Generally, we found the strip mode needing to be reset afterward (though not always, sometimes they came back on with a power cycle).

posts.name: Bryn Dole - programming mentor FRC 2930
posts.cooked:
Michael_2930:

One thing some people have observed is that at least a couple of times, the LEDs have gone out after a significant impact,

Indeed, our most recent blinkin failure happened immediately after driving over the cable protector. Not a particularly hard hit, but enough to get the wheels in the air. Look for 2930 in Red in the top left of the screen between 35-37s into the YouTube video. This happened after changing the firmware to disable the button select.

Just checked the logs, and the robot is not browning out at that time. The lowest the voltage goes around the time the LEDs went out was 8.6V, but mostly it is above 10V. The robot is not changing the color of the LEDs at  that time either.

The LEDs came back on after power cycling the robot immediately after the match.

posts.name: hyun
posts.cooked: How exactly did you guys change the blinkin firmware? I’m thinking of just removing the 2 12v modes entirely in the blinkin firmware ino file, but I was wondering if there’s anything else

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: Since this was just bumped, for 2024 the API was simplified. setPulseTime just takes microseconds, so that conversion is no longer necessary.

posts.name: Bryn Dole - programming mentor FRC 2930
posts.cooked:
Firmware for REV Blinkin REV-11-1105. Contribute to FRC-Sonic-Squirrels/Blinkin-Firmware development by creating an account on GitHub.

Here’s a link to the Blinkin Firmware chages we made (a fork of the REV repo). I’m not the one who made that changes. IIRC, we suspected it was a bug in how the blinking was interpreting the PWM modulation when it “glitched”:  voltage spikes or just loose connections (hard hits on the robot were a common trigger). Even after our firmware changes when we thought it was impossible for the rio to switch voltage modes, it did.

Needless to say we’re never putting a blinkin on a comp bot again. We’re using the WPILib AddressableLED class this year.
